Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story:
I glance at the dashboard clock as I pull up to the curb. My passenger, a young man with a relaxed smile, slides into the back seat and tells me he’s heading to a café across town. “No rush,” he says, “I’ve got plenty of time.” I nod, but my mind is already racing. Today is my turn to lead the weekly meditation at the temple, and the session starts in just over an hour. I promised the group I’d be there early to prepare the space, to set the incense and cushions, to greet everyone with calm presence. 

As I drive, I feel the tension coil in my chest. The traffic lights seem longer than usual, and every slow-moving car ahead of me feels like a personal test. I want to offer my passenger a smooth, unhurried ride, to embody the patience I preach as a Buddhist. But the minutes tick by, and I can’t help but worry about letting down my fellow practitioners. My hands grip the wheel tighter. I try to focus on my breath, but the competing demands pull me in opposite directions, and I wonder which role I must disappoint today.
